docs.lead_paragraph: THE health center at West Side Middle School in Groton is the first line of defense for students who are sick or injured, and not just in terms of first aid. In southeastern Connecticut, a shortage of pediatricians and family practitioners excludes many children from private medical care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most mornings at 7 A.M., Sundays included, the dozens of waiting-room chairs are filled with well-turned-out, anxiously hopeful patients, as if at a casting call for a smart urban drama. They have dropped by on their way to midtown Manhattan offices, or flown in from Hong Kong, Jerusalem and Caracas, to visit the in vitro fertilization clinic at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, one of the most renowned in the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: I'LL meet you at the 45th Street entrance of the Pan Am Building," a friend of mine I call City Stroller because of his insatiable thirst for walking the streets of New York, told me as we parted company near Avery Fisher Hall, formerly Philharmonic Hall. "Pan Am Building?" I replied with the sanctimony of one who has inflicted a "gotcha" on an authority. "It doesn't exist anymore, no such thing, flew away with the helicopter roof. It's the Met Life, don't you know?"

headline.main: Puzzling Out the New York City Name Game

docs.lead_paragraph: Yale University has given striking graduate students until noon Tuesday to turn in undergraduates' fall semester grades or face losing their teaching appointments for the next semester. The deadline came in a letter from university officials to part-time acting instructors -- graduate students who run their own classes.

headline.main: Yale Gives Deadline In Instructors' Strike

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR political junkies, 1995 was a fascinating year, with the Republicans gaining control of both houses of Congress and Newt Gingrich attempting to push through his "revolution." Likewise, 1996, a presidential election year, promises to be equally intriguing: which forces -- liberal or conservative -- will control the country? Does it matter? One who watches closely is Prof. Ray Seidelman, a political science professor at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers since 1982, who specializes in American politics, voting and political participation. He sees the country divided not so much by conservative-vs.-liberal forces as by the fact that so many of the poor and working class disfranchise themselves by not voting. The result, he says, is an elite democracy.

headline.main: Westchester Q&A: Ray Seidelman;How Nonvoters Affect Government

docs.lead_paragraph: IF the movie "Network" were being remade in 1996, the writers would be well advised to modulate the scene where Howard Beale, the messianic anchorman, implores discontented citizens to shout from their windows. In the updated version, Mr. Beale's call-to-arms might be: "I'm mad as heck and I'm not going to take it anymore!" As the curtain lifts on an uncommonly consequential Presidential campaign season, voters, like an unappreciative audience, are still hissing. They are still cross. They are still cranky. But the raw, tomato-hurling fury that has characterized and transformed modern American politics, and brought a self-described revolutionary named Newt Gingrich to the center of the national political stage, has subsided a bit.

headline.main: Cease-Fire;The Mellowing of The American Voter

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. LEE SILVER, a biology professor at Princeton University, says the work he is doing is so simple that, to prove his point, he is allowing undergraduates to do it. Dr. Silver is among a growing number of scientists searching for genes that predispose people to complex behavioral traits, like aggression or a tendency toward alcoholism or drug abuse or even toward daydreaming or thrill seeking.

headline.main: Is a Gene Making You Read This?

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Tony Sledge, a former cab driver from Fort Greene, was so badly injured in a car accident that his right leg had to be amputated and his shoulder held in place by a piece of metal. He could barely raise his arm, and he could walk only short distances on crutches, so Mr. Sledge applied for Social Security disability benefits. But a doctor's report from the Brooklyn Hospital Center stated that Mr. Sledge, 42, could bend down and touch his toes, had a normal gait and could get on and off the examination table. Based on the report, by Dr. Sophia Schwartzman, the Social Security Administration denied him benefits.

headline.main: Doctor Turned Hospital Into Assembly Line, Patients Say

docs.lead_paragraph: A THREE-YEAR resurgence of cigar smoking has lifted the spirits and lined the pockets of Connecticut's 10 shade tobacco growers, the last of a once-thriving industry that supported hundreds of farmers. But the future of the roughly 2,000 acres of land that they occupy, along with undeveloped land in the north central part of the state, is uncertain. If the farmers continue to prosper, they may retain what they have into the 21st century. If not, a pent-up demand for warehouse and distribution centers by retailers and manufacturers could swallow up whatever is available. Development is on the rise, enhanced by the presence of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks and highway access to Interstates 91 and 84.

headline.main: In the Region/Connecticut;With Cigars in Vogue, Farmers Return to Tobacco

docs.lead_paragraph: In a suspected revenge slaying, a 21-year-old man and his 15-year-old cousin were gunned down early yesterday in the lobby of an apartment house in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said. Soon after the discovery of the two bodies, the police reported receiving calls that the victims, Dwayne Boone of 632 Sterling Place and the teen-ager, Glennis Sanders of 85 Tompkins Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, had been murdered in retaliation for the killing of a man during a holdup at a dice game in October.

headline.main: Two Cousins Fatally Shot; Police See It As Revenge
